Advisors: Andrew Teixeira, Ravindra Datta, Pratap Rao
Title: Feasibility of Ambient Temperature Liquid Metal Air Batteries
Abstract: This project expands upon the work of past research to develop a rechargeable liquid Gallium-Air battery. Gallium is nontoxic, sufficiently reactive, and liquid at low temperatures, ~30 degrees Celsius, making it ideal for this use. Liquid-Metal and Metal-Air batteries have some of the highest theoretical energy densities of any current battery technology; Liquid-Metal-Air batteries are predicted to have the benefits of each while counteracting the drawbacks. Theoretical calculation of a Liquid-Gallium-Air battery produces an energy density value 11 times higher than commercially available lithium ion batteries. A battery with such high energy density would help shift energy dependence away from fossil fuels and towards renewable energy.

Students: Timothy Cotter, Allyson Kearns, Allison Sichler, Aiden Wright
Title: The Development and Study of Organic Composites
Abstract: To alleviate modern society’s reliance on plastic, our team explored compostable alternatives to petroleum based polymers. This study examines the processability and properties of organic fiber-reinforced composites, constructed using a combination of PLA or a potato starch based matrix, and natural fibers such as flax, cotton, or jute. To characterize the resulting material, our team studied the matrix-fiber adhesion, chemical composition, mechanical strength, and biodegradability of the samples. This investigation allowed our team to infer potential applications for our product, as well as issue guidance for future exploration.

Students: Sarah Duquette, Ashley Kishibay, Alexandra Miller, Benjamin Schade
Advisors: John Sullivan, Stephen Kmiotek, Jerome Schaufeld
Title: Onsite Plastic Recycling for Rural Places
Abstract: Estimates show that the United States recycles less than 10% of plastic waste. In an effort to improve this situation, the group developed and tested a prototype to recycle expanded polystyrene - a form of plastic that has exorbitant shipping costs due to its high volume to weight ratio. Our prototype design reduces shipping costs by two orders of magnitude enabling small municipalities to recycle with minimal investment. Cost estimates for a local compaction facility and transport to a state-wide recycling facility are less than the current land-fill expenses for small municipalities.

Students: Emily Hammer, Amelia Brown, Everest Peacock
Title: Scale Up of Pit Fire Geometry Experiment
Abstract: Research and small-scale tests have indicated that combustion of trash fires can be improved through burning the trash in pits with optimized geometry. In order to investigate the potential to create a cleaner way to burn trash, these small-scale tests must be scaled up. Potential benefits to burning trash in a pit instead of on open ground include reductions of burn injuries, increased rate of burning which would lead to less exposure to harmful smoke, and an increase in burn efficiency which would reduce the amount of harmful particulates in the smoke. The goal of our project is to create a large-scale experimental set-up to effectively investigate the effect of pit geometry on the combustion of trash.

Students: Rosa Reynoso, Van W. Harting, Isabel M. Azevedo, Madison E. Cunniff, Rediet Merra Tegegne
Title: Co-Designing for Gold Mining Safety
Abstract: The use of mercury in artisanal and small scale gold mining in Ghana poses serious environmental and health risks. The purpose of this project is twofold; to improve safety by prototyping a device to reduce mercury exposure, and to document our novel co-design approach. We prototyped three iterations of retorts, blending our technical expertise with miners’ local expertise. By allowing miners to lead the stages of design and grounding our partnership in mutual respect and sharing of ideas, our partners recognized their own capacity to shape their own outcomes. Future efforts can include further technical and field testing to improve device function and manufacturability and an implementation scheme to expand access to these devices.

Title: Optimization of Catalytic Microreactors for Ammonia Decomposition
Abstract: Hydrogen is an attractive source for zero-emission energy because of its usefulness in fuel cell batteries. However, traditional methods to capture hydrogen for use in these cells, such as steam reforming, produce greenhouse gases. Ammonia decomposition is a promising method to produce hydrogen, and our research explored the possibility of using catalyst-coated microreactors to improve the decomposition reaction. Microreactors provide lower pressure drops, are isothermal, and are compact, which leads to effective heat transfer. We created stainless steel microreactors that are wall-coated with a nickel alumina catalyst. We tested the scale-up potential of our reactors by modeling the heat loss during the decomposition process.

Title: Continuous Reactor Anaerobic Digestion with Batch Reactor Pretreatment for Barley Bagasse
Abstract: This project used a continuous reactor to study the anaerobic digestion of barley bagasse using a batch reactor as a source of daily feed. Anaerobic digestion is the process of microorganisms digesting organic material in the absence of oxygen: producing biogas, which is useful as a versatile fuel because of its methane content. This project analyzed the resultant biogas and considered reactor stability metrics such as alkalinity, chemical oxygen demand, and ammoniacal nitrogen content. On average, the continuous reactor produced 745 mL of biogas per day with 58% methane. The energy production potential of the reactor was considered to analyze whether this method could be a sustainable energy source for the brewing industry.

Students: Michaela Johnson, Jason Rivers, Summer Thurlow
Title: Paclitaxel Release System
Abstract: Taxus suspension cultures can be used to produce paclitaxel (PTX), an anticancer compound. This project investigates the use of a plant cell culture (PCC) local delivery system for PTX through exploring the increased retention of PTX and other specialized metabolites through wash processes, the optimization of drug delivery through natural and synthetic polymer hydrogels, the cytotoxic effects PTX has on breast cancer cells, and the pharmacokinetics of the optimized system. Through these aims, the administration of PTX can be shifted from systemic to local, thus decreasing the adverse side effects that are associated with current cancer therapies.

Title: Developing Reusable Microfluidic Hormone Test Chip
Abstract: Hormone testing is a necessary indicator of the health of people worldwide. A microfluidic chip is often used to evaluate the presence or levels of a specific hormone in a person’s body. In some places these tests can be inaccessible to the common person. Another issue regarding hormone testing is any user would be using it repeatedly, not just once, making this a recurring expense. These tests are single use, and commonly made of non-biodegradable materials such as plastic. To make these tests more accessible and sustainable, this paper will explore the options for creating a reusable microfluidic hormone testing system, which could be used repeatedly and regularly to check the health of its user.

Title: Growing Fungal Highways for a Synthetic Soil Microbiome
Abstract: This project’s goal is to provide new methods of exploring the interactions and growth of soil bacteria and fungi in their natural environment. Within the ecosystem, these microbes improve plant biodiversity and productivity, maintain soil structure and composition, decompose biomass, and recycle nutrients. Specifically, the fungal hyphal network can transport nutrients, chemical signals, and bacteria over long distances. This capability can be harnessed for a variety of applications in agriculture, bioremediation, and synthetic biology. In this work, we conducted initial fungal growth studies, measuring growth rates in a variety of culture conditions and in soil. This work enables lab-grown fungal highways to study the soil microbiome.

Title: Lignocellulosic Hydrolysate Detoxification
Abstract: Lignocellulose biomass is a common feedstock for second-generation ethanol. However, when lignocellulosic biomass is hydrolyzed, fermentation inhibitors along with the preferred sugar molecules are created. The goal of this project was to detoxify the lignocellulosic biomass and remove all furanic compounds using biochar as an adsorbent. To understand the efficiency of biochar as an adsorbent, the results will be compared with activated charcoal adsorption.

Students: Max Moran, Tala Calvi, Devin Hainsworth
Title: Biomass Pretreatment
Abstract: The goal of this project is to examine the pretreatment of biomass for production of biomass. Biomass is used for the production of biofuels in alternatives to fossil based fuels. Pretreatment of biomass is important in the production process of lignocellulosic biofuels. We will give this data to UMass Lowell for producing simulation of swelling biofuels.

Students: Alice Morgan, Amparo Cosio, Sydney Packard
Title: Engineering Kombucha: Characterization of K. xylinus
Abstract: Komagataeibacter xylinus is a relatively under-examined strain of bacteria found in kombucha that produces cellulose. K. xylinus has the potential to allow for the mass production of bacterial cellulose, but there are no adapted protocols for high-throughput transformation methods. This project sought to develop a chemical transformation method for K. xylinus by adapting existing protocols for similar bacteria. A second objective was to investigate the bacteria’s cellulose production process. Due to time constraints neither objective was fully accomplished, but the study collected significant research on K. xylinus, contributing to the characterization of the bacteria and future efforts to achieve a scalable transformation method.

Title: Valorization of Poultry Feather Protein Residues using Subcritical Water Hydrolysis
Abstract: This experiment analyzed the effect of subcritical water hydrolysis on natural poultry feathers for the isolation of high-value amino acids. Subcritical water hydrolysis is the process by which water in the range of 100 - 374 C converts and breaks down biomass into micromolecules. Often this process can result in the production of high-value products from poultry feathers. Poultry feathers are approximately 90 percent protein, which suggests that poultry feathers can be used to produce valuable amino acids. A non-toxic and environmentally favorable way to break down these poultry feathers is by subcritical water hydrolysis. In particular, this experiment focused on studying the effect of operating temperature on the hydrolysate.

Title: Analysis of Food and Green Waste Bio-Oil and It's Applications on the WPI Campus
Abstract: The goal of this project is to find the optimal ratio of food waste to green waste that produces the most crude bio-oil. Then, an energy analysis is performed on the bio-oil to see if it could be upgraded and used to offset some of WPI's energy consumption using the food waste from the campus dining hall and the green waste from general landscaping on campus.

Title: Hydrolytic Pretreatment of Macauba Shells for Anaerobic Digestion
Abstract: This experiment examined the effect of sub-critical water hydrolysis as a pretreatment for anaerobic digestion of macauba nut shells for production of renewable methane. Renewable natural gas was made from macauba nut shells with and without pretreatment using subcritical water hydrolysis as the pretreatment. The control reactor had an average solid content of 16.9%, an accumulated volume of biogas of 17.6 liters and an average methane composition of 38%. The pretreatment reactor had an average solids content of 4.4%, an accumulated volume of 22.5 liters and an average methane composition of 67%. The accumulated energy of the pretreated reactor was 97.9 MJ/kg and the control reactor was 4.69 MJ/kg.

Students: Jeffrey Page, Joseph Esposito, Douglas TheBerge, Philip Smolitsky
Title: Waste-Oils to Sustainable Aromatics with ZSM-5: Catalyst Activity, Stability, and Reaction Pathway
Abstract: Addressing climate change will require production of sustainable alternatives to common chemicals derived from fossil fuels. Of these chemicals, benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene (BTEX) specifically are highly valuable industrial precursors. Prior research has shown BTEX production from the break down of palmitic acid (PA)—a common component of waste oils—with ZSM-5 catalyst, but several questions remain about catalyst deactivation and reaction pathway. In this MQP, catalyst activity, stability, as well as the reaction pathway of PA cracking with a minority loading of water and ZSM-5 were investigated at supercritical (SC) conditions. Minority SC water was found to increase catalyst activity and reduce catalyst deactivation.

Students: Christopher Tracy, Benson Colella, Nicholas Roschewsk
Title: Analysis of a Runaway Reaction
Abstract: The goal of this project is to predict thermal runaway. When furfuryl alcohol is catalyzed by acid, an explosive reaction occurs. This happened in industry where luckily no one was hurt. After the incident, a gap in knowledge about the polymerization of furfuryl alcohol was found. Our project intended to fill some of this gap and study the kinetics of the polymerization reaction. We produced a mathematical model to predict an explosive reaction based on the parameters of reactants added, vessel size, and starting temperature. We then compared our model to experimental results.
